wikipedia_page.main: Patricia Mary, Baroness Carson (5 March 1929, Oreston - 13 October 2014, Ghent) was an Anglo-Belgian historian and author.

response: * Patricia Carson, James Van Artevelde: The Man from Ghent (Ghent, 1980).

During the 15th century when the city of Ghent was at odds with the Duke of Burgundy, the council often sat elsewhere – at various times in Kortrijk, Dendermonde, Ypres or Bruges. It was finally re-established to Ghent in 1498.Patricia Carson, The Fair Face of Flanders (revised edition, Tielt, 2001), p. 113. The counts of Flanders had recognised the appellate jurisdiction of the Parlement of Paris for suits arising in those parts of Flanders anciently attached to the kingdom of France (essentially those parts west of the river Scheldt), but in 1521 Charles V decreed that the Great Council of Mechelen had sole appellate jurisdiction for the whole county of Flanders. By the Treaty of Cambrai (1529), Francis I of France renounced all claim to sovereignty or jurisdiction in Flanders.
Van Caenegem was married to the British-born historian Patricia Carson, who was ennobled in 1996 with the personal title of Baroness.
*Patricia Carson, 85, British historian and author.A Fair Face passed away - Patricia Carson (1929-2014)
